emergency.subtitle: If you suspect you are currently being scammed or have been victimized, take immediate action.

actions.title: Stop All Communication Immediately
actions.description: Cease contact with the suspected scammer. Do not respond to calls, emails, or messages.

actions.title: Halt All Financial Transactions
actions.description: Stop any pending transfers, payments, or shipments immediately. Contact your bank or payment provider.

actions.title: File a ScamNemesis Report
actions.description: Document the incident in our system to warn others and create an official record.

understanding.title: Understanding Scams: Definition and Mechanics
understanding.subtitle: Understanding how scams work is the first step in protecting yourself and others.

whatIsScam.title: What is a Scam?
whatIsScam.content1: A scam is a fraudulent scheme designed to deceive individuals into parting with money, personal information, or assets through false promises, misrepresentation, or manipulation.
whatIsScam.content2: Scams exploit human psychology, trust, and emotional vulnerabilities to bypass rational decision-making.

steps.desc: Initial outreach via phone, email, social media, or in person
Offer something desirable or create fear/urgency
Establish credibility through fake credentials or emotional connection
Cut contact after obtaining what they want

psychology.title: Psychology of Scam Victimization
psychology.subtitle: Scammers use 6 primary psychological manipulation methods to exploit human behavior and bypass critical thinking.

tactics.title: Authority Impersonation
tactics.description: Pretending to be officials, banks, or experts to exploit trust in legitimate institutions.

tactics.title: Artificial Time Pressure
tactics.description: Creating false urgency to prevent careful thought and rational decision-making.

tactics.title: False Social Proof
tactics.description: Fabricating testimonials, reviews, and success stories to create illusion of legitimacy.

tactics.title: Emotional Manipulation
tactics.description: Exploiting fear, greed, loneliness, or compassion to override logical thinking.

tactics.title: Trust-Building Deception
tactics.description: Investing weeks or months building relationships before making fraudulent requests.

tactics.title: Information Asymmetry
tactics.description: Using technical jargon and complexity to confuse victims and discourage questions.

scamCategories.title: 12 Most Prevalent Scam Categories
scamCategories.subtitle: Familiarize yourself with these common fraud schemes to recognize and avoid them.

types.name: Investment Fraud
types.description: Fake investment opportunities promising guaranteed high returns with little to no risk.
types.tip: Verify all investments through official regulatory databases before committing funds.

types.name: Romance Scams
types.description: Criminals build fake romantic relationships over time to extract money from victims.
types.tip: Never send money to someone you have not met in person, regardless of the story.

types.name: Phishing Attacks
types.description: Fake emails, texts, or websites designed to steal login credentials and personal data.
types.tip: Always verify sender addresses and navigate directly to official websites, never via links.

types.name: E-commerce Fraud
types.description: Fake online stores, non-delivery of goods, or counterfeit product sales.
types.tip: Research sellers, check reviews from multiple sources, and use secure payment methods.

types.name: Technical Support Fraud
types.description: Scammers pose as tech support claiming your computer has problems requiring immediate fixes.
types.tip: Legitimate companies do not call unsolicited. Hang up and contact official support directly.

types.name: Employment Scams
types.description: Fake job offers requiring upfront payment for training, equipment, or background checks.
types.tip: Real employers never ask you to pay for the opportunity to work for them.

types.name: Rental Fraud
types.description: Fake property listings with below-market rates requiring deposits before viewing.
types.tip: Always view properties in person and verify ownership before transferring any money.

types.name: Lottery/Prize Scams
types.description: Notifications of fake winnings requiring fees or taxes to be paid before receiving the prize.
types.tip: Legitimate lotteries deduct fees from winnings. You cannot win contests you did not enter.

types.name: Charity Fraud
types.description: Fake charitable organizations exploiting disasters, holidays, or emotional causes.
types.tip: Research charities through official databases and donate directly through verified websites.

types.name: Government Impersonation
types.description: Criminals posing as IRS, Social Security, immigration, or law enforcement officials.
types.tip: Government agencies communicate via official mail, not threatening phone calls demanding immediate payment.

types.name: Healthcare Fraud
types.description: Fake medical treatments, miracle cures, or fraudulent health insurance schemes.
types.tip: Consult licensed healthcare providers and verify insurance through official company channels.

types.name: Home Service Scams
types.description: Fake contractors demanding large advance payments then disappearing without completing work.
types.tip: Verify licenses, check references, and never pay the full amount upfront.

immediateAction.title: Immediate Action Protocol: First 24 Hours
immediateAction.subtitle: If you've been scammed, take these 5 critical steps within 24 hours to maximize recovery chances and prevent further damage.

steps.title: Stop all communication and transfers immediately
steps.description: Cease contact with the suspected scammer and halt any ongoing transactions.

steps.title: Contact your financial institution within 24 hours
steps.description: Report fraudulent transactions and request holds, reversals, or account freezes as needed.

steps.title: Secure all accounts with new passwords
steps.description: Change passwords for all potentially compromised accounts using strong, unique credentials.

steps.title: Document everything comprehensively
steps.description: Save all communications, receipts, screenshots, and transaction records before they disappear.

steps.title: File official reports with authorities
steps.description: Report to local police, FBI IC3, FTC, and relevant regulatory bodies to create official record.

evidence.title: Evidence Collection and Documentation Standards
evidence.subtitle: Proper documentation is critical for law enforcement investigations and potential fund recovery. Preserve everything.

bestPractices.title: Documentation Best Practices
items: Create timestamped backups of all evidence
Organize files by date and category
Keep both digital and physical copies
Do not edit original files (make copies for notes)
Store evidence securely with restricted access
